awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: 3D Concrete Printing with Macro-Micro Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
The construction industry is a critical element of the US economy, but construction remains one of the least automated and lowest productivity industries in the world. Much construction activity is low-tech, injury-prone and dependent on semi-skilled labor. Within the industry, the pouring of concrete is a pervasive process. This award supports research in robotic systems for pouring concrete. The research will generate the fundamental knowledge required to design robots which can pour concrete with greater efficiency and precision than current manual methods, while working intimately and safely with human workers. The multidisciplinary research will be conducted by a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students that includes women and underrepresented minority students. The resulting robot systems will be lightweight, widely deployable, low-cost, and inherently safe. Therefore, results from this research will improve work flow, enhance build quality, support workers, and enhance the competitiveness of the US construction industry.

The concrete deployment robot system will be based on a new cable-driven macro/micro design, featuring an under-actuated cable robot as the macro unit, with a cable-driven continuum robot, integrated with the concrete delivery hose, as the micro unit. The macro-micro system represents a significant innovation in cable-actuated co-robots.  Coordination of the dual system presents new and challenging problems in the control of interconnected dynamical systems subject to differential-algebraic constraints and the research will generate the fundamental knowledge required to solve the associated problems. The need for the robot to safely and robustly assist human coworkers further motivates an innovative data-driven methodology for providing situational awareness of the dynamic construction environment. The focus on dexterous concrete pouring represents a quantum leap for civil engineering in enabling additive 3D printing of concrete structures with enhanced functionalities, and the related fundamental materials research will yield new understanding of the most suitable concrete formulations for robotic deployment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
In this project, the investigators conducted basic research into the use of novel robots for 3D printing of concrete on construction sites. A key goal for the project was to provide the cement hose depositing the concrete with greater maneuverability by modifying the hose to become a smooth-backboned "continuum" robot. Another key goal was to enhance the workspace and flexibility of the system via positioning of the robotic "micro" hose with a cable-driven parallel robot "macro" system. To this end, fundamental theoretical analysis was performed, new algorithms generated and validated in simulations, prototype robots developed, and 3D concrete printing experiments conducted using them. Basic research in developing cementitious materials suitable for robotic 3D printing was conducted.

The results of the research demonstrated that 3D printing of concrete with robot hoses is feasible. The research in cementitious materials generated new understanding of how to combine the basic elements of cement to create 3D printable cement, notably on the relative effects of the individual components on the materials properties of 3D printable cementitious materials.

The research concerning the "micro" hose led to the creation of new understanding of tendon-actuated continuum robots. Specifically, we discovered that the hose "shrunk" slightly in length (formally, it exhibited axial compression) during operation. This change in length was not predicted by the existing theory, and caused errors in the concrete printing. To fix this issue, we generated new theory which takes into account this axial compression, in a way that does not require the addition of extra sensing to the system. This theory expands the existing knowledge base on tendon-actuated continuum robots.

In the research concerning the cable-actuated parallel "macro" robot,  we conducted fundamental research into the -- potentially severe -- effects of a cable failure/breakage. Specifically, we developed a novel Cable Failure Identification and Recovery Framework -- relying solely on end-effector information, this framework not only supports failure detection but also supports recovery of the original/lost workspace (by exploiting reconfiguration of the remaining cable-base winches).

The research supported the theses of four Ph.D. students, two female and two male, as well as two undergraduate students (one female, one male) under a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) supplement. The results of the research were taken out into the wider community, in particular describing the project and exhibiting some of the robot hardware to thousands of people during the "Artisphere" exhibition in Greenville, SC, in the summer of 2022.


Last Modified: 10/30/2023
Modified by: Ian D Walker

A key goal for the project was to provide the cement hose depositing the concrete with greater maneuverability by modifying the hose to become a smooth-backboned "continuum" robot. The results of the research demonstrated that 3D printing of concrete with robot hoses is feasible. The research supported the theses of four Ph.D. students, two female and two male, as well as two undergraduate students (one female, one male) under a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) supplement.
